Subject: Re: Is it possible to set mole fractions with variables???
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=336712078; y=3bw7sd3FlKqIaalpbYcbrwZU4m3kMg03KFtHrLyOWj11

Thanks Anatoli and Dave for your kind reply. What I meant (not sure 
what a=
 "functor" is) is to be able to set the mole fractions by using 
variables =
instead of the string in the set command. For example, I 
would like to do =
something like this:

mole_CH4 =3D 1.0
mole_O2 =3D 1/phi*(1+y/4.0))  # phi =
and y are computed in my code.
mole_N2 =3D (1/phi*(1+y/4.0)*(Xn2/Xo2))  # X=
n2, Xo2 are mole fractions.

Then set the mole fractions with something lik=
e this:
gas.set(T=3D900.0,P=3D1.0e5,X=3D'CH4:mole_CH4,O2:mole_O2,N2:mole_N2=
')

Right now, I just compute the new stoichiometry (according to my phi) 
=
and then modify the value in the set command. This is not a big deal, 
but =
it takes some time when you want to do the calculation for many 
conditions=
. Anatoli's approach is a very good idea. However, it still 
requires the m=
ole fractions to be given as strings, which do not 
support arithmetic oper=
ations. Thank you both again for your interest 
and help. Best Regards, Pet=
er

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "avmokhov" <avmokhov@...> wrote:
>
> Hi=
 Peter,
> For me it is also not clear what do you want to do. Do you mean t=
o 
> add a function to Cantera, which returns a calculated composition 
> b=
ased on phi such as
> string mixture_composition(const string& fuel, const =
string& 
> Oxidizer, double phi) ?
> 
> It is quite easy to implement and I=
 use this function in my 
> calculations. Than you can do something like th=
at 
> 
> double T =3D 300;
> double P =3D 1.0e5;
> string fuel =3D "CH4:0.8=
,H2:0.2";
> string oxidizer =3D "O2:0.2,N2:0.8";
> double phi =3D 1.0;
> ga=
s.set(T, P, mixture_composition(fuel, oxidizer, phi)); 
> 
> Best regards, =
Anatoli
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, Dave Goodwin <dgoodwin@> wrote=
:
> >
> > I don't understand what you want to do - what are the data types =

> of  
> > things like "CH4:m ole"?  I infer that you want to give functor=
s, 
> not  
> > numerical values, as input parameters. Is that what you mea=
n? If 
> so,  
> > I think it is a very interesting idea and I'll have to t=
hink a 
bit  
> > about whether that will work or not!
> > 
> > Dave
> > 
>=
 > 
> > On Mar 3, 2008, at 1:17 PM, Peter Perez wrote:
> > 
> > >
> > > Dea=
r Cantera Users:
> > >
> > > I wonder if anyone has been successful in para=
metrizing the
> > > set.molefraction() function in Python. I mean, instead =
of give 
the
> > > composition as:
> > >
> > > gas.set(T =3D 900.0, P =3D 1=
.0e5, X =3D 'CH4:1,O2:2,N2:7.52')
> > >
> > > We could give something like:=

> > >
> > > gas1.set(T =3D 900.0, P =3D 1.0e5, X =3D  
> > > 'CH4:mole_CH4=
,O2:mole_O2,N2:mole_N2')
> > >
> > > Where mole_CH4, mole_O2 and mole_N2 ar=
e previously calculated 
as a
> > > function of the fuel injection rate, ma=
ss air flow and 
equivalence
> > > ratio. Any hint or experience on this wi=
ll be much appreciated. 
> Thank
> > > you very much for your kind attentio=
n.
